eNumber.comment: Animal genes damage, possible risk to conception and cancer. JECFA still evaluating re reproductive toxicity. Orange-yellow color, derived from turmeric, a member of the ginger family.
eNumber.name: Curcumin (from turmeric)

eNumber.comment: Yellow color, it's a vitamin!!!.
eNumber.name: Riboflavin (Vitamin B2), formerly called lactoflavin

eNumber.comment: Linked to hyperactivity, skin rashes, migraines, behavioural probs, thyroid probs, chromosome damage. Banned in Norway and Austria. Yellow color, commonly used, the HACSG* recommends to avoid it. Typical products are soft drinks, confectionary, cordials, pickles.
eNumber.name: Tartrazine (FD&C Yellow 5)

eNumber.comment: Linked to hyperactivity.
eNumber.name: Alkannin

eNumber.comment: Linked to hyperactivity, skin rashes, asthmatics should avoid. Banned in USA and Norway - previously banned in Australia. Not permitted in Australia.
eNumber.name: Quinoline Yellow WS

eNumber.comment: Yellow color, the HACSG* recommends to avoid it. People who suffer Asthma may also show an allergic reaction to it. Typical products are soft drinks.
eNumber.name: Yellow 2G

eNumber.comment: Suspected carcinogen, allergies, hyperactivity, upset stomach, skin rashes, kidney tumours, chromosomal damage. Banned in Norway. Yellow color, the HACSG* recommends to avoid it. Some people show allergic reactions to it (rashes, swelling, vomiting). Typical products are cordials, confectionary, packet soups.
eNumber.name: Sunset Yellow FCF (Orange Yellow S, FD&C Yellow 6)

eNumber.comment: Linked to hyperactivity, possibly toxic to embryo. Red color, the HASCG* recommends to avoid it. Rarely used.
eNumber.name: Cochineal, Carminic acid, Carmine (Natural Red 4)
Citrus Red 2
eNumber.status: Approved in the United States only for use in colouring the skin of oranges.

eNumber.comment: Suspected carcinogen, mutagen, skin rashes, oedema, hyperactivity. Banned in Sweden, USA, Austria and Norway. Red color, the HASCG* recommends to avoid it. Sensitive people and asthmatics may show allergic reactions to it. Typical products are confectionary, marzipan, jelly crystals.
eNumber.name: Carmoisine (azorubine)

eNumber.comment: Suspected carcinogen, mutagen, linked to hyperactivity, asthma and eczema. Banned in USA (1976), Russia, Austria, Norway and others. Purplish-red color, banned in the United States in 1976, still used in Australia. Avoid it! Typical products are cake mixes, fruit-flavoured fillings, jelly crystals.
eNumber.name: Amaranth (FD&C Red 2)

eNumber.comment: Suspected carcinogen, linked to hyperactivity and asthma. Banned in USA and Norway. Red color, the HACSG* recommends to avoid it. Asthmatics and people with aspirin sensitivity may show allergic reactions.
eNumber.name: Ponceau 4R (Cochineal Red A, Brilliant Scarlet 4R)
Ponceau SX, Scarlet GN
eNumber.status: Only permitted for externally applied drugs and cosmetics in the US.

eNumber.comment: Suspected carcinogen, linked to thyroid abnormality, brain dsyfunction, hyperactivity, light sensitivity. Banned in Norway. Red color, the HACSG* recommends to avoid it. Might increase thyroid hormone levels and lead to hyperthyroidism. Can cause sensitivity to light. Typical products are custard mix, biscuits, glace' cherries, canned cherries and strawberries.
eNumber.name: Erythrosine (FD&C Red 3)

eNumber.comment: Not permitted in Australia.
eNumber.name: Red 2G

eNumber.comment: Suspected carcinogen, skin rashes, hypersensitivity. Banned in Denmark, Belgium, France, Germany, Switzerland, Austria, Norway. Red color, may be an allergen in allergic skin conditions. Typical products are biscuits, cake mixes, fruit-flavoured fillings.
eNumber.name: Allura Red AC (FD&C Red 40)

eNumber.comment: Not permitted in Australia.
eNumber.name: Patent Blue V

eNumber.comment: Suspected carcinogen,linked to hyperactivity, nausea, breathing difficulty, skin reactions, blood pressure. Banned in Norway. Blue color, people with allergies should avoid it. May cause nausea, vomiting, high blood pressure, skin rashes, breathing problems and other allergic reactions. Typical products are confectionary, biscuits.
eNumber.name: Indigo carmine (indigotine, FD&C Blue 2)

eNumber.comment: Suspected carcinogen,linked to hyperactivity, asthmatics should avoid. Banned in Belgium, France, Germany, Switzerland, Sweden, Austria, Norway. Blue color, the HACSG* recommends to avoid it.
eNumber.name: Brilliant Blue FCF (FD&C Blue 1)

eNumber.comment: Green to olive color, naturally part of man's diet.
eNumber.name: Chlorophylls and Chlorophyllins: (i) Chlorophylls (ii) Chlorophyllins

eNumber.comment: Olive color, no adverse effects are known.
eNumber.name: Copper complexes of chlorophylls and chlorophyllins (i) Copper complexes of chlorophylls (ii) Copper complexes of chlorophyllins

eNumber.comment: Hypersensitivity, allergic reactions, asthmatics should avoid. Banned in USA, Sweden, Norway, UK. Green color, seems safe in small quantities.
eNumber.name: Green S
Fast Green FCF (FD&C Green 3)
eNumber.status: Approved in the US. Banned in the EU.

eNumber.comment: Linked to gastro intestinal problems, hypersensitivity, saftey suspect. 150(i) seems safest.
eNumber.name: Plain caramel

eNumber.comment: Linked to gastro intestinal problems, hypersensitivity, saftey suspect. 150(i) seems safest.
eNumber.name: Caustic sulphite caramel

eNumber.comment: Linked to gastro intestinal problems, hypersensitivity, saftey suspect. 150(i) seems safest.
eNumber.name: Ammonia caramel

eNumber.comment: Linked to gastro intestinal problems, hypersensitivity, saftey suspect. 150(i) seems safest.
eNumber.name: Sulphite ammonia caramel

eNumber.comment: Linked to bowel disorders, hyperactivity, asthmatics should avoid. Banned in US, Denmark, France, Germany, Switzerland, Sweden, Austria, Norway. Black color, the HACSG* recommends to avoid it.
eNumber.name: Black PN, Brilliant Black BN

eNumber.comment: Suspected carcinogen. Banned in US. Black colour, banned in the United States, still used in Australia.
eNumber.name: Vegetable carbon

eNumber.comment: Not permitted in Australia.
eNumber.name: Brown FK (kipper brown)
eNumber.status: Approved in the EU for dyeing kippers only, however appears to no longer be used.

eNumber.comment: Suspected carcinogen and mutagen. Linked to asthma, skin irritation . Banned in US, Denmark, France, Germany, Switzerland, Sweden, Austria, Norway, Belgium. Brown colour, the HACSG* recommends to avoid it. Typical products are chocolate cake mixes.
eNumber.name: Brown HT (chocolate brown HT)

eNumber.comment: Hypersensitivity, allergic reactions, skin irritations, linked to behaviour and learning problems. Concerns about toxicity still being evaluated by JECFA yet is still freely used.
eNumber.name: Annatto, bixin, norbixin

eNumber.comment: Little info available.
eNumber.name: Paprika oleoresin, Capsanthin, capsorubin

eNumber.comment: Unsuitable for infants and children due to sodium nitrate content. Purple color, no adverse effects are known.
eNumber.name: Beetroot Red, Betanin

eNumber.comment: Asthmatics should avoid. Violet color, seems safe.
eNumber.name: Anthocyanins
eNumber.purpose: Color pH dependent(Red, green and purple ranges)

eNumber.comment: No adverse effects are known.
eNumber.name: Calcium carbonate, Chalk

eNumber.comment: White color, no adverse effects are known.
eNumber.name: Titanium dioxide

eNumber.comment: Possible kidney damage. Suspected neurotoxin. Blindness in dog studies. Seems safe.
eNumber.name: Iron oxides and iron hydroxides

eNumber.comment: New to standards, previously not permitted in Australia. Banned in other countries. Not permitted in Australia.
eNumber.name: Aluminium

eNumber.comment: New to standards, previously not permitted in Australia. Banned in other countries. Not permitted in Australia.
eNumber.name: Silver

eNumber.comment: New to standards, previously not permitted in Australia. Banned in other countries. Not permitted in Australia.
eNumber.name: Gold

eNumber.comment: Not permitted in Australia.
eNumber.name: Pigment Rubine, Lithol Rubine BK

eNumber.comment: Large doses associated with gastric problems, kidney and liver damage. Clarifying agent in alcoholic drinks.
eNumber.name: Tannin

eNumber.comment: Skin irritant, behavioural problems. Asthmatics should avoid. Possible skin irritant.
eNumber.name: Sorbic acid

eNumber.comment: Behavioural problems. Linked to asthma and kidney / liver problems. No known adverse effects.
eNumber.name: Sodium sorbate

eNumber.comment: Possible liver damage, behavioural problems. Linked to asthma. Avoid if kidney or heart problems. No known adverse effects.
eNumber.name: Potassium sorbate

eNumber.comment: Behavioural problems. Linked to Asthma and allergic reactions. No known adverse effects.
eNumber.name: Calcium sorbate

eNumber.comment: Hyperactivity, asthmatics should avoid, possible neurological dysfunctions. The HACSG* recommends to avoid it. Typical products are soft drinks, juices, cordials, chilly pastes.
eNumber.name: Benzoic acid

eNumber.comment: Hyperactivity,asthmatics should avoid, nettle rash, behavioural problems. The HACSG* recommends to avoid it. Typical products see 210.
eNumber.name: Sodium benzoate

eNumber.comment: Asthmatics should avoid, nettle rash, behavioural problems. People with a history of allergies may show allergic reactions. Typical products see210.
eNumber.name: Potassium benzoate

eNumber.comment: Asthmatics should avoid, nettle rash, behavioural problems. See 212.
eNumber.name: Calcium benzoate

eNumber.comment: Not permitted in Australia.
eNumber.name: Ethylparaben (ethyl para-hydroxybenzoate)

eNumber.comment: Not permitted in Australia.
eNumber.name: Sodium ethyl para-hydroxybenzoate

eNumber.comment: Asthmatics should avoid, contact dermatitus, eczema, mouth numbing. Possible contact allergen.
eNumber.name: Propylparaben (propyl para-hydroxybenzoate)

eNumber.comment: Not permitted in Australia.
eNumber.name: Sodium propyl para-hydroxybenzoate

eNumber.comment: Allergic reactions possible - skin and mouth. Allergic reactions possible, mainly affecting the skin.
eNumber.name: Methylparaben (methyl para-hydroxybenzoate)

eNumber.comment: Asthmatics should avoid, gastric irritation / damage, hyperactivity, behavioural problems, poss mutagen. Can be fatal to asthmatics. The HACSG* recommends to avoid it. May cause allergic reactions in asthmatics, destroys vitamin B1, typical products are beer, soft drinks, dried fruit, juices, cordials, wine, vinegar, potato products.
eNumber.name: Sulphur dioxide

eNumber.comment: Asthmatics should avoid, gastric irritation, nausea, nettle rash and swelling , behavioural problems. See 220.
eNumber.name: Sodium sulphite

eNumber.comment: Asthmatics should avoid, gastric irritation, nausea, nettle rash and swelling , behavioural problems. See 220.
eNumber.name: Sodium bisulphite (sodium hydrogen sulphite)

eNumber.comment: Asthmatics should avoid, gastric irritation, nausea, nettle rash and swelling , behavioural problems. See 220.
eNumber.name: Sodium metabisulphite

eNumber.comment: Asthmatics should avoid, gastric irritation, nausea, nettle rash and swelling , behavioural problems. See 220.
eNumber.name: Potassium metabisulphite

eNumber.comment: Asthmatics should avoid, gastric irritation, nausea, nettle rash and swelling , behavioural problems. See 220.
eNumber.name: Potassium sulphite

eNumber.comment: Not permitted in Australia.
eNumber.name: Calcium sulphite

eNumber.comment: Not permitted in Australia.
eNumber.name: Calcium hydrogen sulphite (preservative)

eNumber.comment: Asthmatics should avoid, gastric irritation, nausea, nettle rash and swelling , behavioural problems. See 220.
eNumber.name: Potassium hydrogen sulphite

eNumber.comment: Not permitted in Australia, can be used for agricultural purposes, typical products are citrus fruit.
eNumber.name: Biphenyl, diphenyl

eNumber.comment: Not permitted in Australia, can be used for agricultural purposes, typical products are pears, carrots, peaches, plums, prunes, sweet potatoe, citrus fruit, pineapples, tomatoes, peppers, cherries, nectarines.
eNumber.name: Orthophenyl phenol

eNumber.comment: See 231.
eNumber.name: Sodium orthophenyl phenol

eNumber.comment: Not permitted in Australia, can be used for agricultural purposes, typical products arecitrus fruits, apples, pears, potatoes, bananas, mushrooms, meat, milk.
eNumber.name: Thiabendazole

eNumber.comment: No known adverse effects.
eNumber.name: Nisin

eNumber.comment: Can cause nausea, vomitting, diarrhoea, skin irritation. Sometimes used medically to treat candidiasis, can cause nausea, vomiting, anorexia, diarrhoea and skin irritation. Typical products are meat, cheese.
eNumber.name: Natamycin, Pimaracin

eNumber.comment: Not permitted in Australia.
eNumber.name: Formic acid

eNumber.comment: Not permitted in Australia.
eNumber.name: Sodium formate

eNumber.comment: Not permitted in Australia.
eNumber.name: Calcium formate

eNumber.comment: Not permitted in Australia.
eNumber.name: Hexamine (hexamethylene tetramine)

eNumber.comment: Behavioural problems, asthma, breathing difficulties, headaches, dizziness, possible carcinogen. Prohibited in foods for infants and young children. Not permitted in foods for young children, may cause dizzynesss, headaches, difficult breathing,potential carcinogen, typical products are meat.
eNumber.name: Potassium nitrite

eNumber.comment: Hyperactivity, behavioural probs, asthma, headaches, dizziness, possible carcinogen. Prohibited in foods for infants and young children. The HACSG* recommends to avoid it (see 249).
eNumber.name: Sodium nitrite

eNumber.comment: Hyperactivity, behavioural probs, asthma, headaches, dizziness, possible carcinogen. Prohibited in foods for infants and young children. See 250.
eNumber.name: Sodium nitrate (Chile saltpeter)

eNumber.comment: Hyperactivity, behavioural probs, asthma, headaches, dizziness, possible carcinogen, kidney inflamation. Prohibited in foods for infants and young children. See 249.
eNumber.name: Potassium nitrate (Saltpetre)

eNumber.comment: No known adverse effects.
eNumber.name: Acetic acid (preservative)

eNumber.comment: Those with kidney / liver problems should avoid. Should be avoided by people with impaired kidney function. Typical products are sauces, pickles.
eNumber.name: Potassium acetate (preservative)

eNumber.comment: No known adverse effects.
eNumber.name: Sodium acetates (i) Sodium acetate (ii) Sodium diacetate (sodium hydrogen acetate)

eNumber.comment: Can cause nausea and vomiting.
eNumber.name: Ammonium acetate

eNumber.comment: Not recommended for babies as may be unable to metabolise. Could cause problems in very young babies, typical products are infant formula, confectionary, dressings, soft drinks.
eNumber.name: Lactic acid (preservative)

eNumber.comment: Behavioural and learning problems, headaches. Asthma. No known adverse effects.
eNumber.name: Propionic acid

eNumber.comment: Behavioural and learning problems, headaches. Asthma. May be linked to migraines, typical products are flour products.
eNumber.name: Sodium propionate

eNumber.comment: Behavioural and learning problems,skin irritation, headaches, migraine. Asthma. See 281.
eNumber.name: Calcium propionate

eNumber.comment: Behavioural and learning problems, migraine, headaches. Asthma. See 281.
eNumber.name: Potassium propionate

eNumber.comment: Reproductive and neurotoxicity,teratogen, possible links to infertility, on NIH hazards list. May increase the effect of alcohol, typical products are wine, soft drinks, confectionary.
eNumber.name: Carbon dioxide

eNumber.comment: Not suitable for children as unknown if they can digest it fully, allergic reactions, skin irritations. Infants and young children should avoid it.
eNumber.name: Malic acid (acid)

eNumber.comment: No known adverse effects.
eNumber.name: Fumaric acid

eNumber.comment: Vitamin C.
eNumber.name: Ascorbic acid (Vitamin C)

eNumber.comment: Sodium salt of vitamin C.
eNumber.name: Sodium ascorbate

eNumber.comment: Those susceptible to kidney stones should avoid - otherwise regarded as safe. Vitamin C, may increase the formation of calcium axalate stones.
eNumber.name: Calcium ascorbate

eNumber.comment: Potassium salt of vitamin C.
eNumber.name: Potassium ascorbate

eNumber.comment: Same function as vitamin C.
eNumber.name: Fatty acid esters of ascorbic acid (Ascorbyl palmitate)

eNumber.comment: Suspected carcinogen, asthmatics and aspirin sensitive people should avoid, liver damage, skin irritiations. Prohibited in food for infants and young children as linked to blood disorder. Not permitted in foods for infants and young children, may cause gastric or skin irritation, typical products are margarine, fats, oils.
eNumber.name: Propyl gallate

eNumber.comment: Asthmatics and aspirin sensitive people should avoid, gastric and skin irritations. Prohibited in foods for infants and young children. See 310.
eNumber.name: Octyl gallate

eNumber.comment: Asthmatics and aspirin sensitive people should avoid, gastric and skin irritations. Prohibited in foods for infants and young children - caused deaths in animal tests. See 310.
eNumber.name: Dodecyl gallate

eNumber.comment: No known adverse effects.
eNumber.name: Erythorbin acid

eNumber.comment: No known adverse effects.
eNumber.name: Sodium erythorbin

eNumber.comment: Linked to cancer, birth defects, can cause nausea, vomitting, delerium, collapse, dermatitis. Dose of 5g is fatal - avoid it. The HACSG* recommends to avoid it. May cause nausea, vomiting, delirium. A dose of 5g is considered fatal. Typical products are fats, oils, margarine.
eNumber.name: tert-Butylhydroquinone (TBHQ)

eNumber.comment: Serious concerns about carcinogenic and estrogenic effects, asthmatics and aspirin sensitive people should avoid, causes metabolic changes and accumulates in body fat. Banned in Japan in 1958 -Not permitted in foods for infants and young children. The HACSG* recommends to avoid it. Not permitted in foods for infants or young children. Typical products are fats, oils, margarine, nuts, instant potato products.
eNumber.name: Butylated hydroxyanisole (BHA)

eNumber.comment: Suspected carcinogen, asthmatics and aspirin sensitive people should avoid, skin irritation. Prohibited in foods for infants and young children. The HACSG* recommend to avoid it. Not permitted in foods for infants or young children. Typical products are nuts.
eNumber.name: Butylated hydroxytoluene (BHT)

eNumber.comment: Nutritious and non-toxic.
eNumber.name: Lecithin

eNumber.comment: Young children with lactose intolerance may show adverse reactions.
eNumber.name: Sodium lactate

eNumber.comment: See 325.
eNumber.name: Potassium lactate (antioxidant)

eNumber.comment: See 325.
eNumber.name: Calcium lactate

eNumber.comment: See 325.
eNumber.name: Ammonium lactate

eNumber.comment: See 325.
eNumber.name: Magnesium lactate

eNumber.comment: Occurs naturally in citrus fruits.
eNumber.name: Citric acid

eNumber.comment: No known adverse effects.
eNumber.name: Sodium citrates (i) Monosodium citrate (ii) Disodium citrate (iii) Sodium citrate (trisodium citrate)

eNumber.comment: No known adverse effects.
eNumber.name: Potassium citrates (i) Monopotassium citrate (ii) Potassium citrate (tripotassium citrate)

eNumber.comment: No known adverse effects in small quantities.
eNumber.name: Calcium citrates (i) Monocalcium citrate (ii) Dicalcium citrate (iii) Calcium citrate (tricalcium citrate)

eNumber.comment: No known adverse effects in small quantities.
eNumber.name: Tartaric acid (L(+)-)

eNumber.comment: No known adverse effects.
eNumber.name: Sodium tartrates (i) Monosodium tartrate (ii), Disodium tartrate

eNumber.comment: Those with kidney impairment should avoid. No known adverse effects.
eNumber.name: Potassium tartrates (i) Monopotassium tartrate (cream of tartar) (ii) Dipotassium tartrate

eNumber.comment: Those with kidney impairment should avoid. Not recommended for those with heart probs or high blood pressure. No known adverse effects.
eNumber.name: Sodium potassium tartrate

eNumber.comment: Neurotoxicity, eye and skin irritant,large doses can lead to adicosis and hypocalcaemia. No known adverse effects.
eNumber.name: Orthophosphoric acid

eNumber.comment: High intakes may upset the calcium/phosphorus equilibrium.
eNumber.name: Sodium phosphates (i) Monosodium phosphate (ii) Disodium phosphate (iii) Trisodium phosphate

eNumber.comment: See 339.
eNumber.name: Potassium phosphates (i) Monopotassium phosphate (ii) Dipotassium phosphate (iii) Tripotassium phosphate

eNumber.comment: No known adverse effects.
eNumber.name: Calcium phosphates (i) Monocalcium phosphate (ii) Dicalcium phosphate (iii) Tricalcium phosphate

eNumber.comment: New to standards.
eNumber.name: Ammonium phosphates: (i) monoammonium phosphate (ii) diammonium phosphate

eNumber.comment: Essential minerals.
eNumber.name: Magnesium phosphates (i) monomagnesium phosphate (ii) Dimagnesium phosphate
eNumber.status: Approved in the EU. This additive is under discussion and may be included in a future amendment to the Directive on miscellaneous additives.

eNumber.comment: Unsuitable for infants and young children, skin irritations.
eNumber.name: Ammonium malate

eNumber.comment: No known adverse effects.
eNumber.name: Sodium malates (i) Sodium malate (ii) Sodium hydrogen malate

eNumber.comment: No known adverse effects.
eNumber.name: Potassium malate

eNumber.comment: No known adverse effects.
eNumber.name: Calcium malates (i) Calcium malate (ii) Calcium hydrogen malate

eNumber.comment: No known adverse effects.
eNumber.name: Metatartaric acid

eNumber.comment: New to standards. Seems safe.
eNumber.name: Calcium tartrate

eNumber.comment: Severe eye irritant, toxic effect in rat studies including death - avoid it. No known adverse effects.
eNumber.name: Adipic acid

eNumber.comment: No known adverse effects.
eNumber.name: Potassium adipate

eNumber.comment: New to standards.
eNumber.name: Ammonium adipate

eNumber.comment: Not permitted in Australia.
eNumber.name: Succinic acid

eNumber.comment: No known adverse effects.
eNumber.name: Sodium fumarate

eNumber.comment: No known adverse effects.
eNumber.name: Potassium fumarate

eNumber.comment: No known adverse effects.
eNumber.name: Calcium fumarate

eNumber.comment: New to standards.
eNumber.name: Ammonium fumarate

eNumber.comment: Not permitted in Australia.
eNumber.name: 1,4-Heptonolactone

eNumber.comment: May interfere with liver and pancreas function - more study needed. May interfere with liver and pancreas function.
eNumber.name: Triammonium citrate

eNumber.comment: Essential mineral.
eNumber.name: Ammonium ferric citrate

eNumber.comment: Muscle cramps , kidney damage, gastrointestinal problems, banned in some countries. Not permitted in Australia.
eNumber.name: Calcium disodium ethylene diamine tetraacetate, (Calcium disodium EDTA)

eNumber.comment: No known adverse effects in small quantities. Large quantities can inhibit the absorption of some nutrients.
eNumber.name: Alginic acid (thickener) (stabiliser) (gelling agent)

eNumber.comment: See 400.
eNumber.name: Sodium alginate (thickener) (stabiliser) (gelling agent)

eNumber.comment: See 400.
eNumber.name: Potassium alginate (thickener) (stabiliser) (gelling agent)

eNumber.comment: See 400.
eNumber.name: Ammonium alginate (thickener) (stabiliser)

eNumber.comment: See 400.
eNumber.name: Calcium alginate (thickener) (stabiliser) (gelling agent)

eNumber.comment: Allergic reactions common, avoid in pregnancy - more study required. No known adverse effects.
eNumber.name: Propane-1,2-diol alginate (Propylene glycol alginate) (thickener) (stabiliser)

eNumber.comment: See 400.
eNumber.name: Agar (thickener) (gelling agent)

eNumber.comment: Suspected carcinogen, linked to ulcerative colitus, damage to the immune system, concern about birth defects. Do not give to infants and young children -more work needed. Seems quite safe in small quantities.
eNumber.name: Carrageenan (thickener) (stabiliser) (gelling agent)

eNumber.comment: Suspected carcinogen, linked to ulcerative colitus, damage to the immune system, concern about birth defects. New to standards - do not give to infants and young children.
eNumber.name: Processed eucheuma seaweed (thickener) (stabiliser) (gelling agent)

eNumber.comment: Allergic reactions , possible weak carcinogen - more work required.
eNumber.name: Arabinogalactan

eNumber.comment: Large amounts may cause abdominal pain, diarrhoea, cough in infants, allergic reactions. No known adverse effects in small quantities, may lower chlesterol levels.
eNumber.name: Locust bean gum (Carob gum) (thickener) (stabiliser) (gelling agent)

eNumber.comment: See 410.
eNumber.name: Guar gum (thickener)

eNumber.comment: Asthma, skin rashes, gastrointestinal unpsets, contact dermatitus. Possible contact allergy.
eNumber.name: Tragacanth (thickener) (stabiliser)

eNumber.comment: Asthma, skin rashes in sensitive people. Possible allergen, soothes irritations of mucous membranes.
eNumber.name: Acacia gum (gum arabic) (thickener) (stabiliser)

eNumber.comment: No known adverse effects.
eNumber.name: Xanthan gum (thickener)

eNumber.comment: Asthma. Urticaria, gastrointestinal upsets, dermatitus. Possible allergen.
eNumber.name: Karaya gum (thickener) (stabiliser)

eNumber.comment: Not suitable for diabetics, infants and young children, liver toxicity, gastrointestinal upsets. Prohibited in foods for infants and young children. Not permitted in foods for infants and young children, can cause gastric disturbance. Typical products are dried fruits, confectionary, pastries, low caorie foods.
eNumber.name: Sorbitol (i) Sorbitol (ii) Sorbitol syrup (emulsifier) (sweetener)

eNumber.comment: Not for diabetics, infants and young children, or those with kidney / liver impairment. Linked to hyperactivity, kidney damage. On NIH Hazards list. Possible allergen, may cause nausea, vomiting, diarrhoea. Typical products are low calorie foods.
eNumber.name: Mannitol (anti-caking agent)

eNumber.comment: Headaches, high blood sugar levels, eye skin irritation in sensitive people. Large quantities can cause headaches, thirst, nausea and high blood sugar levels. Typical products are liquers, confectionary, dried fruit, low calorie foods.
eNumber.name: Glycerol (emulsifier)

eNumber.comment: Suspected carcinogen, skin allergies - new to standard.
eNumber.name: Polyoxyethene (40) stearate

eNumber.comment: Suspected carinogen - more work needed. Not permitted in Australia.
eNumber.name: Polyoxyethene (20) sorbitan monolaurate (polysorbate 20)

eNumber.comment: Suspected carinogen - more work needed. May increase the absorption of fat-soluble substances.
eNumber.name: Polyoxyethene (20) sorbitan monooleate (polysorbate 80)

eNumber.comment: Not permitted in Australia.
eNumber.name: Polyoxyethene (20) sorbitan monopalmitate (polysorbate 40)

eNumber.comment: Suspected carcinogen - more testing needed. See 433.
eNumber.name: Polyoxyethene (20) sorbitan monostearate (polysorbate 60)

eNumber.comment: Suspected carcinogen - more testing needed. See 433.
eNumber.name: Polyoxyethene (20) sorbitan tristearate (polysorbate 65)

eNumber.comment: Possible allergen, may contain 220, asthmatics and people allergic to sulphites beware!!!!!.
eNumber.name: Gelatine (emulsifier)

eNumber.comment: No known adverse effects.
eNumber.name: Ammonium phosphatides

eNumber.comment: Headaches, high blood sugar levels, eye skin irritation in sensitive people.
eNumber.name: Glycerol esters of wood rosins

eNumber.comment: Linked to kidney stones in susceptible people, otherwise regarded as safe. High intakes may upset the calcium/phosphate equilibrium.
eNumber.name: Diphosphates (i) Disodium diphosphate (ii) Trisodium diphosphate (iii) Tetrasodium diphosphate (iv) Dipotassium diphosphate (v) Tetrapotassium diphosphate (vi) Dicalcium diphosphate (vii) Calcium dihydrogen diphosphate

eNumber.comment: Linked to kidney stones in susceptible people, otherwise regarded as safe.
eNumber.name: Triphosphates (i) Sodium triphosphate (pentasodium triphosphate) (ii) Pentapotassium triphosphate

eNumber.comment: Linked to kidney stones in susceptible people, otherwise regarded as safe.
eNumber.name: Polyphosphates (i) Sodium polyphosphates (ii) Potassium polyphosphates (iii) Sodium calcium polyphosphate (iv) Calcium polyphosphates (v) Ammonium polyphosphate

eNumber.comment: Most sources regard as safe although banned in UK in baby food only. No adverse effects known.
eNumber.name: Cellulose (i) Microcrystalline cellulose (ii) Powdered cellulose

eNumber.comment: Can cause flatulence, distension, intestinal obstruction.
eNumber.name: Methyl cellulose

eNumber.comment: Not permitted in Australia.
eNumber.name: Hydroxypropyl cellulose

eNumber.comment: No known adverse effects.
eNumber.name: Hypromellose (hydroxypropyl methylcellulose)

eNumber.comment: Flatulence, intestinal upsets, diarrhoea. No known adverse effects.
eNumber.name: Ethyl methyl cellulose

eNumber.comment: Suspected carcinogen, flatulence, intestinal discomfort, diarrhoea. No known adverse effects.
eNumber.name: Carboxymethyl cellulose, Sodium carboxy methyl cellulose
Crosslinked sodium carboxymethyl cellulose (Croscarmellose)
eNumber.status: Approved in the EU. This additive is under discussion and may be included in a future amendment to the Directive on miscellaneous additives

eNumber.comment: Previously permitted in Australia , but no longer included in standards. No known adverse effects.
eNumber.name: Enzymically hydrolysed carboxymethylcellulose
Sodium, potassium and calcium salts of fatty acids (emulsifier)

eNumber.comment: No known adverse effects.
eNumber.name: Mono- and diglycerides of fatty acids (glyceryl monostearate, glyceryl distearate)
Acetic acid esters of mono- and diglycerides of fatty acids
Lactic acid esters of mono- and diglycerides of fatty acids
Citric acid esters of mono- and diglycerides of fatty acids
Tartaric acid esters of mono- and diglycerides of fatty acids

eNumber.comment: Headaches, high blood sugar levels, eye skin irritation in sensitive people. JECFA still evaluating.
eNumber.name: Mono- and diacetyl tartaric acid esters of mono- and diglycerides of fatty acids
Mixed acetic and tartaric acid esters of mono- and diglycerides of fatty acids

eNumber.comment: No known adverse effects.
eNumber.name: Sucrose esters of fatty acids

eNumber.comment: Not permitted in Australia.
eNumber.name: Sucroglycerides

eNumber.comment: No known adverse effects.
eNumber.name: Polyglycerol esters of fatty acids

eNumber.comment: No known adverse effects.
eNumber.name: Polyglycerol polyricinoleate

eNumber.comment: Derived from propylene glycol. No known adverse effects.
eNumber.name: Propane-1,2-diol esters of fatty acids, propylene glycol esters of fatty acids
Lactylated fatty acid esters of glycerol and propane-1
Thermally oxidized soya bean oil interacted with mono- and diglycerides of fatty acids

eNumber.comment: More testing being done especially in relation to children and infants . Awaiting results of studies.
eNumber.name: Dioctyl sodium sulphosuccinate

eNumber.comment: No known adverse effects.
eNumber.name: Sodium stearoyl-2-lactylate

eNumber.comment: Adverse reactions have occurred in animal tests. No known adverse effects.
eNumber.name: Calcium stearoyl-2-lactylate

eNumber.comment: Not permitted in Australia.
eNumber.name: Stearyl tartrate

eNumber.comment: Caused growth retardation in animal studies- may cause liver bile duct changes. No known adverse effects.
eNumber.name: Sorbitan monostearate

eNumber.comment: May increase th absorption of fat-soluble substances.
eNumber.name: Sorbitan tristearate

eNumber.comment: Not permitted in Australia.
eNumber.name: Sorbitan monolaurate

eNumber.comment: Not permitted in Australia.
eNumber.name: Sorbitan monooleate

eNumber.comment: Not permitted in Australia.
eNumber.name: Sorbitan monopalmitate
Partial polyglycerol esters of polycondensed fatty acids of castor oil

eNumber.comment: Regarded as safe in small amounts - some sources list as possible teratogen in large doses. No known adverse effects in small quantities.
eNumber.name: Sodium carbonates (i) Sodium carbonate (ii) Sodium bicarbonate (Sodium hydrogen carbonate) (iii) Sodium sesquicarbonate (acidity regulator)

eNumber.comment: No known adverse effects.
eNumber.name: Potassium carbonates (i) Potassium carbonate (ii) Potassium bicarbonate (Potassium hydrogen carbonate)

eNumber.comment: Can irritate mucous membranes and lead to skin and scalp irritations in some people. Irritant to mucous membranes.
eNumber.name: Ammonium carbonates (i) Ammonium carbonate (ii) Ammonium bicarbonate (Ammonium hydrogen carbonate)

eNumber.comment: Medically used as an antacid and laxative.
eNumber.name: Magnesium carbonates (i) Magnesium carbonate (ii) Magnesium bicarbonate Magnesium hydrogen carbonate

eNumber.comment: Stomach and mouth irritant - some sources list as possible teratogen. Safe in small quantities.
eNumber.name: Hydrochloric acid

eNumber.comment: Associated with gastric ulcers, circulatory collapse, nausea, liver toxicity. Should not be given to children. Large quantities can cause gastric ulceration.
eNumber.name: Potassium chloride (gelling agent)

eNumber.comment: Stomach irritant in sensitive people. No known adverse effects.
eNumber.name: Calcium chloride (sequestrant)

eNumber.comment: Large amounts can cause acidosis - nausea, headaches, insomnia. Those with kidney / lver probs should avoid. Should be avoided by people with impaired liver or kidney function. Typical products are flour products.
eNumber.name: Ammonium chloride, ammonia solution (acidity regulator)

eNumber.comment: Caused kidney damage in dogs so those with kidney damage may wish to avoid. Magnesium is an essential mineral.
eNumber.name: Magnesium chloride

eNumber.comment: Nausea, headache, gastric upset. Skin and mucous membrane irritant.
eNumber.name: Stannous chloride

eNumber.comment: Not permitted in Australia.
eNumber.name: Sulphuric acid

eNumber.comment: Unsuitable for infants and children and those with kidney /liver probs due to high sodium content - Skin irritant. May upset the body's water balance.
eNumber.name: Sodium sulphates (i) Sodium sulphate (ii)

eNumber.comment: Regarded as safe in small doses. No known adverse effects.
eNumber.name: Potassium Sulphates (i) Potassium Sulphate (ii)

eNumber.comment: No known adverse effects.
eNumber.name: Calcium sulphate

eNumber.comment: Laxative effect, low blood pressure, drowsiness, those with kidney damage should avoid. A laxative.
eNumber.name: Magnesium sulphate (Epsom salts), (acidity regulator)

eNumber.comment: Linked to gastrointestinal problems,those with kidney / liver problems should avoid, neurotoxicity. Essential mineral.
eNumber.name: Copper(II) sulphate

eNumber.comment: Not permitted in Australia.
eNumber.name: Sodium hydroxide

eNumber.comment: Not permitted in Australia.
eNumber.name: Potassium hydroxide

eNumber.comment: No adverse effects in small quantities.
eNumber.name: Calcium hydroxide (acidity regulator)

eNumber.comment: Not permitted in Australia.
eNumber.name: Ammonium hydroxide

eNumber.comment: Not permitted in Australia.
eNumber.name: Magnesium hydroxide

eNumber.comment: Safe in small quantities.
eNumber.name: Calcium oxide (acidity regulator)

eNumber.comment: Caused tumours in hamsters - can cause diarrhoea. Not permitted in Australia.
eNumber.name: Magnesium oxide (acidity regulator)

eNumber.comment: No adverse effects known.
eNumber.name: Sodium ferrocyanide (acidity regulator)

eNumber.comment: Low toxicity.
eNumber.name: Potassium ferrocyanide

eNumber.comment: Not permitted in Australia.
eNumber.name: Dicalcium diphosphate (acidity regulator)

eNumber.comment: Thought to release aluminium during digestion - concerns about skeletal abnormalities, dementia, Parkinsons type illness. Not permitted in Australia.
eNumber.name: Sodium aluminium phosphate (i) Acidic (ii) Basic

eNumber.comment: No known adverse effects.
eNumber.name: Bone phosphate (Essentiale Calcium Phosphate, Tribasic)

eNumber.comment: Not permitted in Australia.
eNumber.name: Calcium polyphosphate

eNumber.comment: Not permitted in Australia.
eNumber.name: Ammonium polyphosphate
Sodium Silicates (i) Sodium silicate (ii) Sodium metasilicate

eNumber.comment: No adverse effects are known in food use.
eNumber.name: Silicon dioxide (Silica)

eNumber.comment: No known adverse effects, antacid.
eNumber.name: Calcium silicate

eNumber.comment: Linked to Alzeihmers and nerve damage, bone diseases, kidney damage, neurotoxicity. Aluminium is known to be neurtoxic.
eNumber.name: Sodium aluminosilicate (sodium aluminium silicate)

eNumber.comment: Linked to Alzeihmers and nerve damage, bone diseases, kidney damage, neurotoxicity.
eNumber.name: Potassium aluminium silicate

eNumber.comment: Linked to Alzeihmers and nerve damage, bone diseases, kidney damage, neurotoxicity. See 554.
eNumber.name: Calcium aluminosilicate (calcium aluminium silicate)

eNumber.comment: No known adverse effects.
eNumber.name: Bentonite

eNumber.comment: No known adverse effects.
eNumber.name: Aluminium silicate (Kaolin)

eNumber.comment: Little info available.
eNumber.name: Potassium silicate

eNumber.comment: Can cause allergic creactions in sensitive people - skin irritant. No known adverse effects.
eNumber.name: Fatty acids

eNumber.comment: No known adverse effects in food use.
eNumber.name: Magnesium stearate, calcium stearate (emulsifier)

eNumber.comment: No known adverse effects.
eNumber.name: Glucono delta-lactone (acidity regulator)

eNumber.comment: Not permitted in Australia.
eNumber.name: Sodium gluconate

eNumber.comment: No known adverse effects.
eNumber.name: Potassium gluconate

eNumber.comment: No known adverse effects.
eNumber.name: Calcium gluconate

eNumber.comment: Diarrhoea, vomitting, gastrointestinal upsets. Research showed it causd tumours in mice. Regard with caution. Seems safe in small quantities.
eNumber.name: Ferrous gluconate

eNumber.comment: New to standards - no info avail - regard with caution.
eNumber.name: Magnesium gluconate

eNumber.comment: New to standards - no info avail - regard with caution.
eNumber.name: 4-Hexylresorcinol

eNumber.comment: Unsuitable for infants and children, allergic and hypersensitive reactions, headaches, nausea, sleeplessness. Might cause similar problems as MSG(621), young children should avoid it.
eNumber.name: Glutamic acid

eNumber.comment: Asthma, hyperactivity, depression, mood changes, sleeplessness, nausea, migraine,linked to infertility, teratogen, convulsions, abdominal discomfort. See text re other hidden sources of MSG. Can be an allergen, not permitted in foods for infants and young children.
eNumber.name: Monosodium glutamate (MSG)

eNumber.comment: Problems in people with poor kidney function, headache, asthma, nausea, restlessness. Can cause nausea, vomiting, diarrhoea , abdominal cramps. Typical products are low sodium salt substitutes.
eNumber.name: Monopotassium glutamate

eNumber.comment: Athmatics and aspirin sensitive people should avoid. No known adverse effects.
eNumber.name: Calcium diglutamate

eNumber.comment: Varied allergic reactions in some people. Not recommended for asthmatics. No known adverse effects.
eNumber.name: Monoammonium glutamate

eNumber.comment: Varied allergic reactions in some people. Not recommended for asthmatics. No known adverse effects.
eNumber.name: Magnesium diglutamate

eNumber.comment: Asthmatics and aspirin sensitive people should avoid, linked to hyperactivity, gout sufferers avoid. Prohibited in foods for infants and young children. Not permitted in foods for infants and young children.
eNumber.name: Disodium guanylate, sodium guanylate

eNumber.comment: May trigger gout symptoms, varied reactions reported. Prohibited in foods for infants and young children. Not recommended for asthmatics. Not permitted in foods for infants and young children.
eNumber.name: Disodium inosinate

eNumber.comment: Can cause terrible itchy skin rashes, hyperactivity, sleeplessness, mood changes, many varied ill effects reported.Banned in some other countries -very common in Aust foods. Asthmatics should avoid. Not permitted in Australia.
eNumber.name: Disodium 5'-ribonucleotides

eNumber.comment: No known adverse effects.
eNumber.name: Dimethyl polysiloxane (anti-foaming agent)

eNumber.comment: Occasionally causes allergic reactions in sensitive people. Occasionally causes allergic reactions.
eNumber.name: Beeswax, white and yellow

eNumber.comment: Rare skin allergy reported in sensitive people. Occasionally causes allergic reactions.
eNumber.name: Carnauba wax

eNumber.comment: Rare skin allergy in sensitive people. Occasionally causes irritations of the skin.
eNumber.name: Shellac

eNumber.comment: May inhibit absorption of fats and fat soluble vitamins, mild laxative, there may be a link to bowel cancer. Typical products are dried fruit, confectionary, collagen.
eNumber.name: Paraffins

eNumber.comment: Can inhibit absorbtion of digestive fats , allergic skin reactions possible in some people.
eNumber.name: Petrolatum

eNumber.comment: Not permitted in Australia.
eNumber.name: Crystalline wax
Montanic acid esters, Montan acid esters

eNumber.comment: Linked to cancer, kidney and liver damage. Used as a protective coating on fruits nuts and vegetables.
eNumber.name: Oxidized polyethylene wax, oxidized polyethylene

eNumber.comment: No known adverse effects.
eNumber.name: L-cysteine

eNumber.comment: Large quantities can cause nausea, vomiting, diarrhoea, pain. Typical products are flour products.
eNumber.name: Potassium bromate

eNumber.comment: Destroys nutrients, carcinogen, in some areas tab water is contaminated with it, to make it 'safer' to drink. Typical products are flour products.
eNumber.name: Chlorine

eNumber.comment: Well.....basically see 925.
eNumber.name: Chlorine dioxide (preservative)

eNumber.comment: Asthmatics and people with a history of allergies BEWARE, see 210.
eNumber.name: Benzoyl peroxide (improving agent)
Dichlorodifluoromethane
eNumber.status: Banned in all countries, in compliance with the Montreal Protocol.

eNumber.comment: Caused cancer in animal tests, neurotoxicity, on NIH Hazards list. Petroleum derivitive - avoid it.
eNumber.name: Butane

eNumber.comment: Neurotoxic at high concentrations; on NIH hazards list.
eNumber.name: Isobutane

eNumber.comment: Neurotoxic at high concentrations; on NIH hazards list.
eNumber.name: Propane

eNumber.comment: More info needed - regard with caution.
eNumber.name: Octafluorocyclobutane

eNumber.comment: Caused cancer and tumours in animal tests. ???.
eNumber.name: Acesulfame potassium

eNumber.comment: Linked to many health problmes including cancer, asthma, nausea, depressions, hyperactivity, seizures. The most complained about food additive accounting for 75% of all complaints to FDA. Artificial sweetener, too many adverse effects possible to list !!!.
eNumber.name: Aspartame

eNumber.comment: Suspected carcinogen, animal tests caused testicular damage and embryo damage in rats. Banned in UK and USA in 1970 but still permitted in Australia. Possible carcinogen, not permitted in the USA and UK.
eNumber.name: Cyclamic acid and its sodium and calcium salts, also known as Cyclamate

eNumber.comment: Known carcinogen especially linked to bladder and reproductive cancers. Banned in US in 1977 but reinstated with strict labelling provisions. Not too bad in small amounts, I think.
eNumber.name: Saccharin and its sodium, potassium and calcium salts

eNumber.comment: Linked to neurological and immunological disorders, casued kidney and liver damage in tests. More research needed - avoid it.
eNumber.name: Sucralose (Trichlorogalactosucrose)

eNumber.comment: Liver abnormalities in lab tests - more research needed.
eNumber.name: Alitame

eNumber.comment: Not for use in Infants foods. Little information available - regard with caution. Artificial sweetener; put it that way....the 'acceptable' daily intake has not been specified.
eNumber.name: Thaumatin (sweetener)

eNumber.comment: Little info available - regard with caution until shown to be safe.
eNumber.name: Neotame

eNumber.comment: Caused increased incidence of tumours in animal tests. Mild laxative.
eNumber.name: Maltitol (i) Maltitol (ii) Maltitol syrup (sweetener) (stabiliser)

eNumber.comment: Diarrhoea in high doses, animal tests indicated foetal toxicity.
eNumber.name: Lactitol

eNumber.comment: Diarrheoa, stomach upsets,tumours in animal tests, possible carcinogen. Nobody knows.
eNumber.name: Xylitol

eNumber.comment: Little info available - regard with caution.
eNumber.name: Erythritol

eNumber.comment: Little info available.
eNumber.name: Proteases ((i)Protease, (ii)Papain, (iii)Bromelain, (iv)Ficin)

eNumber.comment: Little info available.
eNumber.name: Glucose oxidase

eNumber.comment: Seems safe in small doses.
eNumber.name: Polydextrose

eNumber.comment: Cancer, lung and kidney damage; liver toxicity, allergic reactions, skin reactions. Made from acetylene, hydrogen, formaldehyde, ammonia. No adverse effects known.
eNumber.name: Polyvinylpyrrolidone

eNumber.comment: No known adverse effects.
eNumber.name: Polyvinylpolypyrrolidone (carrier)

eNumber.comment: Allergic reactions reported, celiacs should avoid.
eNumber.name: Dextrin (Dextrins, roasted starch white and yellow) (stabiliser)

eNumber.comment: Allergic reactions reported, celiacs should avoid.
eNumber.name: Modified starch ((Acid-treated starch) stabiliser)

eNumber.comment: Allergic reactions reported, celiacs should avoid.
eNumber.name: Alkaline modified starch (stabiliser)

eNumber.comment: Linked to asthma as may be treated with sulphur dioxide.
eNumber.name: Bleached starch (stabiliser)

eNumber.comment: Linked to asthma as may be treated with sulphur dioxide.
eNumber.name: Oxidized starch (emulsifier)

eNumber.comment: Allergic reactions reported, celiacs should avoid.
eNumber.name: Enzyme treated starch
Distarch phosphate esterified with sodium trimetasphosphate; esterified with phosphorus oxychloride (stabiliser)

eNumber.comment: Allergic reactions reported, celiacs should avoid.
eNumber.name: Starch acetate esterified with acetic anhydride (stabiliser)
Starch acetate esterified with vinyl acetate (stabiliser)

eNumber.comment: Animal tests showed slowed groth rates and renal lesions.
eNumber.name: Acetylated distarch adipate (stabiliser)

eNumber.comment: Part becomes alcohol in the body.
eNumber.name: Triethyl citrate

eNumber.comment: Alcohol.
eNumber.name: Ethanol

eNumber.comment: Large doses can be toxic , kidney failure, depression of CNS, liver damage, teratogen, on NIH Hazards list. Humectant used to coat fruit and vegetables. Us has placed a total recall of any medication containing this additive yet still permitted in food. Toxic at 'high doses'.
eNumber.name: Propylene glycol

eNumber.comment: Caused renal failure in some tests ; more info needed ; avoid it for now.
eNumber.name: Polyethylene glycol 8000
